Posts.Content: At age 49 my wife started insisting I go for a check up, I refused saying I felt great, which I did. Well after 2 years of her insisting I finally went for a routine physical. The doctor told me he felt something and I should go see a specialist. Which I did. Long story short on my 52nd birthday I was told I had stage 2 prostate cancer. Instead of being upset and feeling sorry for myself I could not help but be thankful for my wife's constant "insisting" that I go for a checkup. I found out a couple of months later that a friend of mine had waited to long to go and get checked, he was diagnosed with stage 4 prostate cancer and at age 60 he passed away. I firmly believe that had he gone sooner he would still be alive today. So I now relate this story to all who will listen. Cause baby you never know.
Posts.Title: Don't be stuborn

Posts.Content: I had the DaVinci surgery, no radiation. It has been 6 months and my Doctor tells me I am ahead of the curve! Thanks for having this forum. My eyes have been opened. I like most people thought cancer only happened to other people. Looking back I was afraid of cancer and unwilling to admit it. A wise man once told me "your a long time dead" enjoy every second of your life. I never quite understood how true that statement was until now.
Posts.Title: Don't be stuborn

Posts.Content: After operation surgeon thrilled after six months no issues then at nine months .08 psa. Had it checked three times to be sure. Going back in two weeks for twelve month check up. My doctor is concerned, and yet I sense he is confused. Any thoughts?
Posts.Title: Psa of 0.1 after op at 6 months no change, at 9 months number is 0.8.

Posts.Content: Sorry guys I am a bit nervous, the number is .18
